description: Japanese - Inari is the rice bearer - god of prosperity, foxes, and abundance in japanese mythology.

historicalContext.sourceText: References in Heian Buddhist texts; Mass devotion from medieval period

shrineSites.name: Fushimi Inari Taisha
shrineSites.significance: Largest Inari shrine; thousands of vermillion torii gates
shrineSites.notes: Most visited Shinto shrine in Japan

shrineSites.name: Inari shrines (thousands of branch shrines)
shrineSites.significance: Most ubiquitous kami worship in Japan
shrineSites.notes: More popular locally than central shrines

festivalAssociations.name: Hatsuuma Festival (First Horse Festival)
festivalAssociations.significance: Major festival; petition for good harvest and prosperity

buddhistEquivalents.connection: Honji suijaku - Inari as Buddhist manifestation

imperialConnections.prosperity: Associated with imperial abundance and longevity

historicalNotes: Highest female kami popularity (exceeds Amaterasu in local devotion)
Merchant adoption - prosperity god for commerce
Gender ambiguity - sometimes male, female, or genderless
Most egalitarian shrine access - ubiquitous folk worship
